You should set the `iceberg.engine.hive.enabled` to `true` in Hive too
@snazy , @nastra : Addressed the comments. Please have a look at it again.

Thanks for taking a look @rdblue.

This is just a follow-up on the issue I found during implementing https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/4662. There I had a failing test which I could have just amended but I thought it was probably worth taking a deeper look and do some cleaning up.
We currently have two separate naming conventions for partition fields which I think is not only a technical debt, but could also be found confusing.
If you consider the following example:
```
    PartitionSpec initialSpec = PartitionSpec.builderFor(SCHEMA).bucket("data", 8).build();
    TestTables.TestTable table = TestTables.create(tableDir, "testnames", SCHEMA, initialSpec, 2);
    table.updateSpec().removeField(bucket("data", 8)).commit();
    table.updateSpec().addField(bucket("data", 8)).commit();
    Partitioning.partitionType(table);
```
We'd end up with
```
struct<1000: data_bucket: optional int, 1001: data_bucket_8: optional int>
```
I guess that means that for metadata queries one should specify different column names while they actually mean the same thing? I recall you have also found it weird in a similar case in @aokolnychyi 's example https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3411#discussion_r823186537 where field names didn't match partition names.

On the other hand you're right of course, as this clean-up needs change in lots of files. These are mostly test files, but I'd rather be worried about the expected API compatibility / behaviour of PartitionSpec class. But then again, maybe this is something that could be fixed before the first major version is GA?
Ok, close it, can you include https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3827?

`hive-dev-box` is being used to run all the unit tests of `hive/master` / metastore integration tests and sometime in the future some smoke tests - so in most cases it should work :)
I don't say it's official...but I think its the easiest way to spin-up Hive for some testing ; there are some timestampted labels if you want to be sure to use a specific version...
cc @openinx @chenjunjiedada @stevenzwu @kbendick , PTAL , thx.
@RussellSpitzer , I added the `distinct` and renamed the function, could you please take another look?
Looks good to me !  Thanks all for the reviewing !

So did you try using the table property `write.parquet.compression-codec`? This is a table property you need to set. It looks like you tried using only the Spark property and never the Iceberg one.

On write I believe you can pass through the same thing as a write option ... but I haven't checked, we don't have it doc'd.

> Do we shade in the ORC Version? Just checking because this could potentially break folks who are using the older versions of ORC at runtime right?

I think we do not shade things. We had to do that in Hive code to avoid clashing versions. We also struggle with Parquet and Avro. It might worth considering shading our own versions of file formats. But it is for another PR.

> > Do we shade in the ORC Version? Just checking because this could potentially break folks who are using the older versions of ORC at runtime right?
> 
> I think we do not shade things. We had to do that in Hive code to avoid clashing versions. We also struggle with Parquet and Avro. It might worth considering shading our own versions of file formats. But it is for another PR.

We do shade parquet. If you open up a spark repl with the iceberg-spark-runtime it’s under `org.apache.iceberg.relocated.org.apache.parquet` I believe. If the others aren’t there (which I believe they are), we should look into adding them.

> > > Do we shade in the ORC Version? Just checking because this could potentially break folks who are using the older versions of ORC at runtime right?
> > 
> > 
> > I think we do not shade things. We had to do that in Hive code to avoid clashing versions. We also struggle with Parquet and Avro. It might worth considering shading our own versions of file formats. But it is for another PR.
> 
> We do shade parquet. If you open up a spark repl with the iceberg-spark-runtime it’s under `org.apache.iceberg.relocated.org.apache.parquet` I believe. If the others aren’t there (which I believe they are), we should look into adding them.

Thanks for the pointer @kbendick. So the issue is solved for all the runtime jars (found the same code for Flink and Hive too). So it is just the direct users of the core jars who has to do that themselves.

there are two potentially expensive steps (1) split discovery (2) emitting the discovered splits to downstream readers. Right now, both steps are executed inside the checkpoint lock. This PR moved the first step outside the checkpoint lock section.
If that's the case let's be sure to note this in the 0.14 release notes

@chenjunjiedada i'm Still wondering a bit whether this should be a part of the result since it's really more of a metric. We don't do anything to these delete files so is it appropriate to return the count?
@RussellSpitzer How about putting the delete metrics inside the braces? Does that look more like metrics instead of results?
Closing this since it is implemented by #4262.

Yes the table property `write.parquet.compression-codec` is best. It looks like `write-format` can be set as an optiion for individual writes, but for Iceberg, the table level property `write.parquet.compression-codec` is what you want.

You can update it later if you want to try something new, and then future writes to that Iceberg table will use that codec for parquet files. Generally the codec isn't changed very often.

@dhruv-pratap I had to update some of the tests (because the Table object didn't have an identifier property). After fixing this, we got circular imports in the tests and the catalog class because of the annotation import. I've moved those to the `__init__.py` because aliasing types will never introduce any circular import if we keep them separate.

Also as an aside, during the _actual_ release process, we need to tag the SHA we build off of in master as `release-base-X.Y.0` for a new (non-patch) release.

I don’t think that step is automated anywhere but it’s how the next SNAPSHOT version gets its name (via a function in build.gradle).
@amogh-jahagirdar, I agree that we shouldn't remove unreferenced snapshots until they are older than the default expiration timestamp. Good catch!
Hi @rdblue I've updated the PR addressing your comments, could you please take a look again? Thanks!
Looks great! I checked the CI runs and everything looks good. It's also easy to read the results so that's great. Thanks, Fokko!

I think is expected as @RussellSpitzer mentioned in https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/4471#issuecomment-1086660475. The spark procedure has to wait until the computation of the files to actually be deleted. Currently, the results of that computation is collected to the spark driver, and deletion of the files occurs on the driver. Even if the procedure did a distributed deletion of files (not currently done due to concerns of bombarding the underlying FS), the procedure needs to first compute the files to be deleted. So if that's the bottleneck in the collectAsList, then that's expected.

Or is this completely stuck on collect? https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/4471#issuecomment-1140290896 I see this comment
Tests are failing, definitely related to this change. Looking into it.

@chenjunjiedada, what do you think the root cause is in this case? Is it that our matching logic is suboptimal and assigns delete files that actually don't apply (I believe we have partition + min/max stats on file path) or is the job planning slow as we need to open more manifests?

If you measured the performance improvement, where was it? During planning or execution?

> Can spark merge into produces different sequence numbers in the MOR mode?

Spark will write only position delete files and they will have the current table sequence number but apply to data files produced by previous snapshots.

@aokolnychyi , Flink writer only produces position deletes that apply the data files in the same snapshot. The current planning strategy doesn't take advantage of this assumption. Spark creates position deletes that apply to data files in the previous snapshot so we can also add an option to ignore deletes with the same sequence number as data files.
@aokolnychyi, After applying this option the matching deletes of a data file could be significantly reduced and thus improve the read performance. The unit test in this PR is an example.
Thanks, @stevenzwu!
It seems not like a performance bottleneck but a completely stuck
Did you check a thread dump? What makes you think it is stuck?

No, currently you can only Zorder during rewrites. Work to allow Zorder on all writes is ongoing

I'm assuming the second example is with an Iceberg table.

Iceberg does not do purely by name resolution, this is one of the advantages over a system like hive. When a column is dropped all of the data in the table for that column at the time is dropped. If another column is added later with the same name it is treated as a brand new column. Data in old files will not be read because we consider that data to be associated with the old column which doesn't exist (even if it has the same name as a current column)
What is the issue with this?
Hi We are getting the same issue with spark 3.2.1 version and unable to resolve. can anyone please guide us.
Merged!

[doubt] SDK V2 also has a possibility to define [retry policy / condition](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/retry/PredefinedRetryPolicies.html#DEFAULT_RETRY_CONDITION) by override [ClientConfiguration](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/ClientConfiguration.html) while building the s3 client itself, why are we opting do it here via `Tasks` here ?

Hi @Rajashekhar-meesala, is the error message exactly the same? If it is, you need to check all your dependencies including the transitive dependencies to make sure there is no old version(< 4.1.63.Final) of netty buffer get into your Spark runtime.

> > I guess people can use branches for testing new changes without impact the trunk
> 
> yes that is one primary use case. Another one is for a separated branch that maintains a historical snapshot. A compacted version could be updated to the branch for optimized read performance.

Another very common usecase is a separate branch - that maintains a gdpr compliant snapshot.

I like that this consolidates the tasks into the pyproject.toml, however make is much more common. I think we should consider that devs in other parts of the Iceberg codebase may want to run these tests and it's more likely they'd already have make.

The abovementioned issue has been fixed in https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/4899

Based on the discussion at the [Python sync](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oMKodaZJrOJjPfc8PDVAoTdl02eGQKHlhwuggiw7s9U/edit), let's close this for now. We can't integrate the code into our existing codebase, and we don't want to maintain the two separately :)

> I like that this consolidates the tasks into the pyproject.toml, however make is much more common. I think we should consider that devs in other parts of the Iceberg codebase may want to run these tests and it's more likely they'd already have make.

Yes I agree to that, just trying to propose something and get your guys opinion on it. So do you feel if there's any value to merge this as is (without replace the make we had?) or make it the only way (I feel like integrate it directly with poetry is really convenient)

Looks like we need to resolve this conflict now that tox has been replace by pre-commit. @Fokko is there a way to pass the `PYENCHANT_LIBRARY_PATH` to the venv? Would this be done in the Poetry config?

> Just bumped into a similar project: https://github.com/nat-n/poethepoet

- https://pypistats.org/packages/poethepoet
- https://pypistats.org/packages/taskipy
Personally, i dont have strong preference, so I am open to everyone's input, thank you for the quick response
Thanks y'all
Reviewed but i guess it's fine, just a question.  Also, be nice to put a description in pr.
@szehon-ho sorry this was a backport of https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/4919

I agree with proposed above, especially around how we organize the project directory structure. I think `src/iceberg` should go away, and it would be awesome if we can import the same namespace as module name. 

However I do observe some other apache project such as airflow have module named to `apache-airflow` and import namespace to `airflow`. But we have the potential complication of legacy-iceberg project as well as already reserved iceberg middleware project on pypi already https://pypi.org/search/?q=iceberg, so +1 on `pyiceberg` to highlight the difference and avoid misuse

@samredai  there was a discussion at the beginning of python refactoring related to the names: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oMKodaZJrOJjPfc8PDVAoTdl02eGQKHlhwuggiw7s9U/edit#bookmark=id.halmhixpma4k. `py-iceberg` was voted to be the name to be used for pypi.

I'm not sure I fully understand your question. The type is declared as `ARRAY<STRING>` for both of those fields, and an array value was inserted. So that's what's being returned.

What behavior are you expecting?

I spent some time thinking and decided that separate scan task types would work a little bit better. Then we can adapt our readers to handle different task types independently whether we will use a utility or a metadata table scan approach (or both).

Hey @samredai Thank you for bringing this up.

I fully agree. I went for `apache-iceberg` in the PR #[4844](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/4844/files#diff-1a45bd938160f7761769e7b6fbc819d1cc7f84ce37f1a6a23ef83cc4e214abc8R19), but that wasn't intentional. I got that from `apache-airflow` on which I also did a lot of work. @jun-he thanks for pointing out the vote, I was unaware of it. Since there weren't any releases (yet), I figured it was TBD.

I also think that `pyiceberg` is a great pypi package name as it matches the internal name. This will prevent a lot of confusion, and frustration in the end. It also nicely aligns with `pyarrow` and `pyspark`.

With respect to dropping the `src`; a big `+1` from my side. It doesn't add any value in my opinion. It will simplify some things such as being able to import the source without having to install it. Also, I had to explicitly tell this to poetry, since it defaults to non-src projects: https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/4844/files#diff-1a45bd938160f7761769e7b6fbc819d1cc7f84ce37f1a6a23ef83cc4e214abc8R36-R38
Let me take a look.
I feel it is reasonable to have a metadata table like this. I am not sure about the change in `FileScanTask`, though. I also have a few questions related to `FileScanTask` in #4870.

This is something I've observed as well. I think it makes sense to add because it's useful to know what the compression codec is just by the filename (from a user perspective). The parquet page metadata should still be the source of truth when reading the data but it's about more easily identifying what was the codec used when writing the parquet file

> I'm not sure I fully understand your question. The type is declared as `ARRAY<STRING>` for both of those fields, and an array value was inserted. So that's what's being returned.
> 
> What behavior are you expecting?

im so sorry about my pool english, i try to express it once more.
I have created a table named `test`, It contains two columns of type array named `tagGcode` `windowsTagIds`,then insert the value(Array['gcode'],Array['window_tag_id']),when I query this table I expect the following result:
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
|                       tagGcode |                  windowsTagIds |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
|                        [gcode] |                [window_tag_id] |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
but the actual result：
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
|                       tagGcode |                  windowsTagIds |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
|                        [gcode] |                        [gcode] |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
I'm not sure if it's flink's bug or iceberg's bug. 
looking forward to your answer thank you very much!@kbendick 😊

Oh I understand now. That’s my fault I didn’t see the result had the same value.

Can you share either a screenshot of the generated DAG for the insert (and for the read) or attach the output of running EXPLAIN? Explain is documented here: https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-1.13/docs/dev/table/sql/explain/#explain-statements
Also what happens when you simply select *?
+1 for using a metadata table for this. It can then be used in numerous places and for various reasons.

> No, currently you can only Zorder during rewrites. Work to allow Zorder on all writes is ongoing

>

You're right, most of the data I need to store are binary files, so I prefer to use `uncompressed` to speed up reading and writing time.

Inside the broadcast exchange thread also seems to be waiting, I'd check out the stage view, is that a single final task we are waiting for? Or another stage. In the dump I didn't see any executor threads running anything but I didn't look that close. 

I would also just try disabling 
1. Adaptive query planning
2. Broadcast joins

Could be that to broadcast is just not completing due to memory pressure, but nothing in that dump looks iceberg specific to me. Just lots of Spark internals waiting on other spark internals

I would like to contribute this enhancement. One possible approach I can think of is to leverage `SortOrderUtil.buildSortOrder` method whenever a manual Sort Order is passed. This should build a Sort Order using both the table partition spec and the user supplied sort order:

https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/9ab94f87de036c9cd91cf8353906a576b4a516ff/core/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/util/SortOrderUtil.java#L52-L75


Please let me know your thoughts.

What did I miss?  @kbendick
u can try table.newScan().includeColumnStats().planFiles()?

just curious, why wouldn't we want to allow something like `if (Objects.nonNull(x))`? The checkstyle message suggests to use `Preconditions.checkNotNull` instead, but that's not really the same. I can see why we'd want to use `Preconditions.checkNotNull` rather than `Objects.requireNonNull` but not why we'd prevent usage of `Objects.nonNull`, since it's just returning a `boolean`
@kbendick @rdblue , Port to Flink 1.15 now, PTAL.

I would like to add an example where I had to add a fake column in order to mitigate the problem. There is a long type column which contains time with nanoseconds precision. I want to have a partition for every 1000 seconds. Unfortunately, `1000 * 10 ** 9` is greater than `Integer.MAX_VALUE`. Trying to use this value would lead to error `Unsupported width for transform: truncate(1000000000000, message_ts)`. So, to deal with it I added a fake column which contains time in seconds, not in nanoseconds.

Actually, I'd prefer to give my +1 to the bound queue solution. Because: 

1.  If there is an existing table which just has included too many manifests (and some of them just have many manifest entries),  then the approaches will just don't work ( such as merging metadata so that those manifest size is an idea size,  tuning the thread size etc).  We can do nothing in the real production environment unless we increment the heap size of spark driver or trino coordinator.   But what if we are not allowed to restart the spark driver & trino coordinator because of the other serving querying jobs ?

2.  Does the blocking queue approach introduce any substantial performance bottleneck ?  If we think the default blocking queue size is a bit small,  then we can increase this default blocking queue size to 10000.  I think most of the cases won't be effected by the default blocking queue size, unless we have an extremely large table with so many manifest entries. But  in the case it seems to be easily OOM if we don't have any limited queue size.
